verses.text: My son, if you have put up security for your neighbor, if you have given your pledge for a stranger,
verses.comment: Here, the wisdom writer warns against rash financial promises. In ancient society, becoming surety meant taking full responsibility, which could disrupt one's household.

verses.text: you are trapped by the words of your mouth, caught by the words you have spoken.
verses.comment: In biblical teaching, words have real consequences; see how this connects to keeping one's word (Ps. 15:4) and the danger of rash vows.

verses.text: So do this, my son, to free yourself, for you have come into the hand of your neighbor: Go, humble yourself, and plead with your neighbor.
verses.comment: Humility is required for reconciliation, echoing Christ's teaching about humility before others (cf. Matt 5:23-24).

verses.text: Do not give sleep to your eyes or slumber to your eyelids.
verses.comment: An urgent call to resolve obligations without delay, reflecting a spiritual principle of prompt repentance.

verses.text: Deliver yourself like a gazelle from the hunter’s hand, like a bird from the hand of the fowler.
verses.comment: Freedom from debt is compared to escaping from a trap, which spiritually suggests liberation from sin.

verses.text: Go to the ant, you sluggard; consider her ways and be wise.
verses.comment: This lesson in diligence directly critiques spiritual laziness; the ant's communal efforts model the virtue of industrious living.

verses.text: Without any chief, officer, or ruler,
verses.comment: The ant does her work unprompted, an image that shows wisdom is self-motivated and not dependent solely on authority.

verses.text: she prepares her food in the summer and gathers her provision in the harvest.
verses.comment: Preparation and foresight are praised here, echoing Biblical teachings on stewardship and care for one’s household.

verses.text: How long will you lie there, O sluggard? When will you arise from your sleep?
verses.comment: Laziness is condemned—spiritually, this recalls the biblical warning to be alert and ready for God's call.

verses.text: A little sleep, a little slumber, a little folding of the hands to rest—
verses.comment: Repeats a familiar proverb about the slow slide into poverty and spiritual negligence.

verses.text: and poverty will come upon you like a robber, and want like an armed man.
verses.comment: Warning about natural and spiritual consequences of sloth; vigilance is a key virtue for discipleship.

verses.text: A worthless person, a wicked man, goes about with a corrupt mouth,
verses.comment: Speech here is directly linked to character; deceitful words are seen as a sign of inward corruption.

verses.text: winking with his eyes, signaling with his feet, gesturing with his fingers,
verses.comment: Describes sly body language—actions that attempt to hide intentions. Christ warns against hypocrisy (cf. Matt 23:27).

verses.text: with deceit in his heart, plotting evil continually, sowing discord.
verses.comment: Here discord is deemed sinful; this highlights the biblical call to peace and unity, themes essential to the church's mission.

verses.text: Therefore calamity will come upon him suddenly; in a moment he will be broken beyond healing.
verses.comment: Destruction for evil is sudden and decisive, a motif seen also in judgment passages elsewhere (Is. 30:13).

verses.text: There are six things the Lord hates, seven that are detestable to him:
verses.comment: This list style is a poetic device signaling emphasis. Divine hatred is reserved for specific destructive behaviors.

verses.text: haughty eyes, a lying tongue, hands that shed innocent blood,
verses.comment: Pride and deceit are grouped with violence; these have major spiritual consequences, each undermining community and justice.

verses.text: a heart that devises wicked plans, feet that hurry to run to evil,
verses.comment: The heart is the source of action; evil originates from within. This anticipates Christ's teaching in Mark 7:21-23.

verses.text: a false witness who breathes out lies, and one who sows discord among brothers.
verses.comment: Unity is prized. The Church is called to be one body, echoing Jesus’ prayer for unity in John 17:21.

verses.text: My son, keep your father’s commandment, and do not forsake your mother’s teaching.
verses.comment: Parental instruction links to the fifth commandment, elevating obedience and respect for tradition as core virtues.

verses.text: Bind them always on your heart; fasten them around your neck.
verses.comment: Storing up wisdom is compared to spiritual disciplines—habitual devotion.

verses.text: When you walk, they will guide you; when you lie down, they will watch over you; and when you awake, they will speak with you.
verses.comment: Wisdom is a constant companion, echoes God's promise of presence (cf. Joshua 1:9, Matt. 28:20).

verses.text: For the commandment is a lamp and the teaching a light, and the corrections of discipline are the way to life,
verses.comment: God’s Word as light connects to Christ as light of the world; spiritual discipline leads to true life.

verses.text: to protect you from the evil woman, from the smooth tongue of the adulteress.
verses.comment: Temptation is personified here, and avoidance is tied to wisdom; spiritual purity is stressed as a feature of holy living.

verses.text: Do not desire her beauty in your heart, and do not let her capture you with her eyelashes.
verses.comment: Jesus reiterates this in the Sermon on the Mount—sin often begins in the heart.

verses.text: For a prostitute reduces you to a loaf of bread, and an adulteress hunts for your precious life.
verses.comment: Sin leads to poverty and spiritual ruin; see parallels to warning about spiritual adultery and idolatry.

verses.text: Can a man scoop fire into his lap without his clothes being burned?
verses.comment: Sin’s natural consequences are depicted symbolically; one cannot escape the results of sinful actions.

verses.text: Or can a man walk on hot coals without his feet being scorched?
verses.comment: Continues the theme: sin brings inevitable harm. This verse subtly echoes the tradition of penance and healing.

verses.text: So is he who goes in to his neighbor’s wife; none who touches her will go unpunished.
verses.comment: Direct allusion to the commandment against adultery; discipline is necessary for moral living and flourishing spiritual community.

verses.text: People do not despise a thief if he steals to satisfy his hunger when he is starving;
verses.comment: Here, the text recognizes mitigating circumstances, yet upholds justice—a subtle nod to mercy and restitution.

verses.text: yet if he is caught, he must pay sevenfold; though it may cost him all the goods of his house.
verses.comment: Restoration and penance are necessary. This resonates with practices of restitution seen elsewhere in the Old Testament.

verses.text: He who commits adultery lacks sense; whoever does so destroys himself.
verses.comment: Adultery not only harms others but defiles the soul (cf. 1 Cor. 6:18).

verses.text: He will get wounds and disgrace, and his shame will not be wiped away.
verses.comment: Sin leaves persistent harm. While forgiveness is available, the effects of sin persist—encouraging a penitential outlook.

verses.text: For jealousy arouses a husband's fury, and he will show no mercy when he takes revenge.
verses.comment: Jealousy, here linked to divine and spousal wrath, alludes to exclusive covenant relationship—mirroring God's zeal for His people.

verses.text: He will not accept any compensation; he will refuse any bribe, however great it is.
verses.comment: Justice cannot be bought off, reinforcing spiritual principles of integrity and the seriousness of covenant breaches.
